description: From Middle English dependen, from Old French dependre and Latin dependeō, from Latin dē- + pendeō (“to hang”). In this sense, displaced native Old English hangian (“to hang or depend”).

verbs.description: depend (third-person singular simple present depends, present participle depending, simple past and past participle depended)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, followed by on or upon, formerly also by of) To be contingent or conditioned; to have something as a necessary condition; to hinge on.
examples: We would like to go skiing, but it depends on the amount of snow.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, followed by on or upon) To trust; to have confidence; to rely.
examples: we should all be able to depend on the word or assurance of our friends
we depend on the mailman to come at the usual time.

entries.meaning: (now literary) To hang down; to be sustained by being fastened or attached to something above.
(archaic) To be pending; to be undetermined or undecided.
(transitive) To cause to be contingent or dependent on; to set as a necessity.
